title: Copy current Win7 to USB HDD and boot therefrom

forumNotes.author: rebell
forumNotes.content:
![:sos:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/help.gif) Hello world,  
I'm beginning to think I'm a bit dim. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) I've been reading posts at a number of forums about running Win7 from an USB HDD and my head is spinning. ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) I need some instruction as I've never worked with a lot of the programs (i.e. Grub4dos, grub2, etc.) that people reference in those posts and often the posts seem to be from experts to experts and I don't understand all the terminology. It also seems like often some steps are left out and it's just taken for granted that the other person will know what to do to get there. :smile:   

What I need is a "Booting From USB Drive For Dumbies" apporach from people who have a little patience for a newbie. :smile: My problem seems to be mostly that in order to get the whole picture I've needed to go from post to post and often Forum to Forum for peices of the puzzle and I can't seem to keep them straight. :smile:   

Here is my problem: I have an HP/Compaq laptop and the nVidia GPU is faulty. The optimum fix would be to get a new mobo, but there is a pending law suit that looks to be settled by my being able to get a new machine, therefore I don't want to spend any more money on this one than absolutely necessary. However, it will probably be early next year before I actually see a new machine and I would like to be able to use this one until then. This faulty nVidia chip causes two distinct symptoms: 1) The video won't always work when one firsts presses the power button and this requires turning the machine on and off multiple times until the video finally kicks in (frustrating and tedious, but managable); and 2) the machine does not see the internal HDD, which is fatal. So, my plan was to clone the laptop's HDD to my FreeAgent external USB drive and boot from there. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)   

I have tried several methods and I end up with the same thing, the machine (any machine) refuses to boot from the USB drive. So, it's clear that, assuming it really is possible to do what I want to, I'm doing something (or several things) wrong. So far I have been able to get the laptop to attempt to load Windows from the USB drive, but this always fails and the machine reboots (initiating the frustrating symptom #1 above). When I can finally get it to show the video and the OS attempts to load, I get a screen that say that the load failed due to new hardware and/or software being installed and gives me the option to begin the repair process or to start Windows normally. If I choose "start Windows normally" it immediately drops to a screen that says "The boot selection failed because a required device is inaccessible." Running the startup repair process appears to do nothing as once it is done and I can get it to attempt to load Windows, it goes back to the screen telling me that startup failed and then the screen with "The boot selection failed because a required device is inaccessible" error again and I could do that all day. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)   

So, is there a simple, step-by-step solution for setting up the USB drive to boot Win7? :smile:   

Thanks for your patience. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)

forumNotes.author: ceehoppy
forumNotes.content:
Most of my experience has been on XP machines, but it seems you have 2 problems to overcome. First is that the Win7 OS that you are using for your "build source" has to be functioning, because it needs to see the usb harddrive in order to install the correct drivers. That info is then stored in the registry. Those drivers have to be "pre-loaded" in order for the usb hdd to be able to boot. If you can't boot the laptop at all on Win7 then you can't update those settings. (IF you ever used that usb hdd with the laptop before it failed then you can tweak the registry from another Windows computer.)  
The second problem is that As Far As I Know, Windows needs to see an internal drive during bootup. I have gotten around that on XP by using "embedded drivers" (from my post [here.](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=12587 "External link")) I don't know if these can work on Win7 or if there are Win7 versions. You may be out of luck but it don't hurt to keep trying. ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png)

forumNotes.author: ceehoppy
forumNotes.content:
Most anti-virus programs seem to flag ANY Preinstalled Enviroment (PE) builder (such as winbuilder) as a "trojan" because as part of its build process winbuilder modifies "system" files from the windows installation cd source file. Any program that isn't windows that tries to do that "must" be malware. Do what you feel comfortable with.  
Another possibility would be to download \& run a Linux OS such as Peppermint or Puppy linux. You don't have to install it to the hdd. It won't have the windows functionality that you're used to but, It took about 1 min to boot my pc from a usb flash drive, auto-configured the ethernet card \& I was connected to the web in 10 sec. ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png)
